This verb is used for encounters taking place outdoors. As far as the protagonisthood is concerned, the crucial factor is not the case frame, but word order. In this sense, using the SUP_NOM pattern with the same word order (Sahib-a-l Eldar halt-na) would yield basically the same meaning.

Same as 21.

The gloss like “PFV/IPFV” might look senseless, but in fact the verbs commonly distinguish between radical used in i) perfective forms, ii) imperfective forms and iii) masdar-like forms such as masdar itself, optative and sometimes imperative. So, the gloss here signals the stem that can be used in both perfective and imperfective forms, but not in the masdar-like series of forms, cf. accu- milk.MAS-.
Same as 19.

This is a tricky situation. The explicit SUB/POST case marker is not audible in the actual speech, but it can be pronounced with emphasis (Eldar-a-k(x) galaz is acceptable). For this reason, this form is analyzed as SUB/POSTgalaz.

The reason for this pattern of glossing is the fact that the relationships between the three main stem can be different: mas = ipfv = pfv; mas = ipfv ¹ pfv; mas = pfv ¹ ipfv; ipfv = pfv ¹ mas; mas ¹ ipfv ¹ pfv. In this particular case, t’ü- eat.PFV/MAS is different from ne- eat.IPFV – celui-là pour 3) toutes les formes imperfectives.

However, the latter option with the verb ççağurin there is an implication of some active imvolvement of the X-argument in the search activity. Moreover, some success can be also implied with this verb, as in Za vaz sa qhsan ruş ççağurnuva. ‘J’ai cherché et trouvé pour toi une bonne fille (pour te marier).

Same verb as 38, different pattern. “yuqˈv-a” can be seen as a semi-grammaticalized postposition. The root Yuq’v originally means ‘la taille’ (partie du corps) ou ‘le centre’. But here, the meaning is clightly modified so that the word is halfway to becoming a postposition.

CV, “ccüǧvena” functions as an adverbial expression here and part of the predicate expression. It is possible to insert additional material between “Eldar-a-laa” and “ccüǧvena”, e.g. “ppara” ‘beaucoup’, ‘très’ : Sahib Eldar-a-laa ppara ccüǧvena amuqˈ-na. Besides, it is possible to just drop the second argument and the sentence remains grammatical. Although Ayten adds that “moi, je le sens comme une anaphore zéro : on est toujours en retard par rapport à qqn ou par rapport à soi-même.”
CV. The reason for using the IPFV/PFV gloss is that the verb’s stems are distributed as cca- plough.PFV/IPFV- vs. ccu- plough.MAS-.

comms: Not included in the database because Y is expressed as an NP-internal modifier.
comms_internal: CV. Ayten has provided extensive evidence for treating the genitive noun as an NP-internal component: it is not possible to insert here anything except for attibutes like “bad” (benzin-di-n pis ni ‘une mauvaise odeur d’essence’). For purposes of focusing, Lezgian employs the preverbal position and “Le génitif est normalement focalisé avec sa tête”. The same conclusion emerges from the pseudo-cleft constructions.

Alternative is the structure “Sahib reqi-n an ppatta-z aqat-na” [PN way.OBL-GEN that side.OBL-DAT come_out-AOR]. Ayten maintains that the two structures are equally frequent. I chose this version based on the simplicity criterion: this one is headed by a simplex verb. AB: “Alatin correspond à ‘traverser’ et an ppattaz aqatin à ‘aller de l’autre côté’.”

It is possible to insert material between the genitival NP and “understanding” or else to move the genitival noun around the sentence, cf. “Ina fransuz çˈal-a-n tek sa Sahib ʕavur-d-a aqˈa-zva” [here French language-OBL-GEN only one PN understanding-OBL-IN bump.IPFV-PRS] ‘Ici, il n’y a que Sahib qui comprend le français.’.

Same verb as 86, different pattern. Alternative is “cˈaalapan-di kˈval yaʕa-na” [lightning-ERG house hit.PFV/IPFV-AOR] with the transitive pattern. Ayten did not report any differnce between the two structures in terms of naturalness. The reason I chose this one is because it is intransitive, and also because Ayten mentioned that the other one would be prefereble if the second argument were human (this said, she did not calim that this one is actually preferred with ‘house’ as the second argument).

Same verb as in 2, 42, different pattern. Alternative is “Lale-di sa gada xa-na” [PN-ERG one son give_birth.IPFV/PFV-AOR] with the transitive pattern. Ayten did not mention any difference between the two structures in terms of naturalness/frequency. The reason I chose this one is because it is intransitive and also because it was reported by Ayten to be more “polite”. Finally, she also mentioned that the alternative transitive pattern is common with animals and implies some more intimate register.
Same verb as 79, different pattern.

Alternative is “Sahib Lale-di-k darixmiș xha-nva” [PN PN-OBL-SUB/POST miss_VN become.PFV-PRF] with the NOM_SUB/POST pattern. I chose this version because the one with “darixmiș” is a direct borrowing from Azerbaijani. Besides, the structure I chose implies a stronger feeling that is typical of situation when one has not seen another person or a home village for a long time. "gala" est une copule locative, il n’y a pas de masdar ; mais on peut utiliser le verbe ‘devenir’ jen.

comms: The combination "avaz fin" yields the relevant meaning only in combination with the postposition "ccüǧvena".
comms_internal: CV. “Avaz” is optional here. Here, ccüǧvena seems to function as a postposition. Here are Ayten’s comments on this: Il me semble que là, ccüǧvena fonctionne plutôt comme une postposition. On peut avoir le même sens et exactement la même structure avec un autre verbe : hatin ‘get’ (hat-nva au lieu de fi-zva). On peut déplacer le génitif (Eldaran) en début de phrase pour focaliser tout le procès (le fait que les gens le suivent). Mais même là, ça ne marche pas toujours. Lorsque l’objet un seul terme (par ex. Sahib), on ne dira pas Eldar-a-n Sahib ccüǧvena (ava-z) fi-zva, on mettra l’objet devant le verbe ‘aller’ : Eldar-a-n ccüǧvena (ava-z) Sahib fi-zva. Lorsque l’objet est composé de plusieurs termes, ça semble mieux marcher : Eldar-a-n sa sürü ayalar ccüǧvena (ava-z) fi-zva ‘Un groupe d’enfants suivent Eldar’. Et on fait une pause après le sujet.

CV. Same verb as in 92, different pattern. Alternative is “Sahib-a raduva-di-z yob gu-zva” [PN-ERG radio-OBL-DAT ear give.IPFV/MAS-PRS] with the ERG_DAT pattern. The reason I chose this one is bacause it was also suggested by Ramazan Mamedshaxov. Ayten maintains there is no semantic difference between the two structures.
